newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Foreign banks offer to lend Manila c. bank funds.
newsitem.headline: Foreign banks offer to lend Manila c. bank funds.

text.p: Foreign banks offered to extend loans to the Philippine central bank to help build buffer its international reserves, central bank governor Gabriel Singson said on Thursday.
Singson, however, declined the offers, saying the International Monetary Fund (IMF) had promised to make available a total of $1.050 billion under the existing Extended Fund Facility.
He added another $400 million is available under a parallel financing by the Japan Export-Import Bank.
"As compared to 1983, our credit remains good ... I have received several offers from foreign banks," Singson told reporters.
"I was made to understand that it's going to be easy for them to raise the money."
"I said 'I don't need it,'" he added.
Singson said the central bank has not made a decision on whether to draw down the IMF loan.
The Philippine gross international reserves had been whittled down to $9.7 billion as of Monday after selling more than $1.5 billion to defend the peso since the start of the month.
